Of visage deep-wrinkled with care,</br>His temples a chaplet surround,</br>With oak-leaves and acorns his hair,</br>And starwort with saffron, is bound.</br>The dam'sen her purple bestows,</br>A sash o'er his shoulder to throw;</br>In negligence easy it flows,</br>Immingled with spots of the sloe.

His right hand a scorpion suspends,</br>High-lifted it writhes in the air;</br>From his left a rush-basket impends,</br>Replete with the walnut and pear.</br>His franchise it is to convoke</br>Thick fogs of blue mist on the hill,</br>Ascending like columns of smoke,</br>Exhal'd from the vale-loving rill.

He comes — shall my Muse wake the reed?</br>Ah, where are the notes of the bough,</br>When whilom the beech on the mead</br>Attested the villager's vow!</br>When Philomel's pastoral lay</br>Pour'd forth her melodious pain;</br>The kids with the lambkins in play,</br>Skipp'd frolicksome over the plain.

It is not for her in the grove</br>To sing of past pleasures serene,</br>When zephyrs invited to love,</br>And Delia was extacy's queen.</br>When near the smooth lapse of the brook,</br>I sought, thro' the whispering vale,</br>The roses which, painting her crook,</br>Compar'd to her blushes, were pale.

No more to the brook must I stray,</br>From the whispering valley exil'd,</br>No longer those zephyrs shall play</br>Round Delia that linger'd and smil'd.</br>Farewell to the white-flaunting hop,</br>The garden so sweet to the sight;</br>The woodbine faint-blooming I'll crop,</br>Convey to my fair with delight.

I'll gather autumnal perfume;</br>The suckle rejects not her sweet;</br>Convulvus offers her bloom</br>To decorate Delia's retreat.</br>The pheasant I'd bear to my maid,</br>But shrink from the present with fear,</br>Lest, into fresh sorrow betray'd,</br>Her eyes are suffus'd with a tear.

To earth's fost'ring bosom the swain,</br>Tenacious of nature's command,</br>Commits with attention the grain,</br>Not ungrateful to Industry's hand.</br>The martin our caves has forsook,</br>The woodcock revisits the glen,</br>The mallard repairs to the brook,</br>The wild-goose abandons the fen.

Shall rapine with murder be join'd?</br>O spare from perdition the hive!</br>Some practice by far less unkind</br>To plunder its treasures contrive.—</br>Now hear the gay pack o'er the field,</br>In pursuit of the fugitive hare:</br>No longer in safety conceal'd,</br>She trusts to the brake or the tare.

But who is this envoy of woes,</br>That wakes with Aurora's first ray,</br>His song of complaint to disclose</br>From the vine or the jessamine's spray?</br>He sings desolations to come;</br>Stern Winter predicts from aloof;</br>My shed, social bird, be thy home,</br>Securely perch under my roof.

Dost grieve that the summer is past?</br>The trees their green ornaments shed?</br>That omens of Winter in haste</br>Impending press over thy head?</br>Prolong, tuneful red-breast, thy strains;</br>Contagions shall usher thy moan;</br>My sympathies share in thy pains,</br>The sorrows, poor bird, be my own!

Pomona, in straw-colour'd vest,</br>With berry strung black solitaire,</br>The gossamer's gauze on her breast,</br>And marigold beams in her hair.</br>October, 'tis said in the close,</br>Paid court to her presence and shape;</br>Vertumnus in jealousy rose,</br>And thought 'twas the God of the Grape.

But he was derang'd in the vale,</br>Whilst Satyrs his orgies sustain;</br>My path from his feasts I'll curtail,</br>Reject his incontinent train.</br>Yet, Bacchus, to honour thy sway,</br>The fig and the vine let me bring,</br>Should the Muse for the present delay</br>The games of the vintage to sing.

Now mid-day is silent around,</br>The gloom of ag'd cypress I'll seek,</br>The turf that with osiers fresh bound</br>My recent dejection shall speak.</br>Leander, my much-valued friend,</br>The Muse's memorial essays,</br>From friendship in sadness to send</br>What elegy weaves into lays.

The Virtues resorted to see</br>Thy solitude's sacred retreat,</br>Made innocence grandeur to thee,</br>Whose soul was serenity's seat.</br>No wealth nor parade could annoy;</br>The mines of content were thy own;</br>And competence kindled that joy</br>Which seldom attends on a throne.

Obscurity mark'd his estate,</br>Yet unimpar'd health was his lot;</br>He scorn'd the least wish to be great,</br>Whose pomp was the peace of a cot.</br>How warmly sincere was his strain,</br>With simple morality fraught,</br>Devoutly religious, though plain,</br>He spoke to the God of his Thought.

Ambition unknown to his breast,</br>Unknown ev'ry clamour and strife,</br>Those poisons corrosive of rest,</br>Those Furies that harrow up life.</br>Yet pensive and thoughtful he grew,</br>The mate of his youth was no more;</br>The friend of his age ever true,</br>His feelings intensely deplore.

I saw him one day near the oak</br>That measures a shade of extent;</br>In silence his misery spoke,</br>Deep sorrow to solitude lent.</br>His brow was as dark as the shade</br>October had spread o'er the dell,</br>Nor long did he grieve in the glade,</br>But languishing droop'd till he fell.</br>
